name: Ziad Ahmed
bio: Yale ‘21 | NYC | CEO of @juvconsulting | @forbes #30Under30 | american-muslim speaker

social_posts.post_text: would write a full recap of my surreal experience at #bofvoices — but don’t gotta bc you can listen to a bit via slide two (and more via @bof’s podcast). for now, the most emphatic thank you @imranamed — what an honor it is to be in community with you ❤️

was a part of a @vice debate amongst asian americans across the political spectrum — and im the type of person who has read all 4,243 of the youtube comments so far — and while i wish i was the type of person who cared less what strangers on the internet say about me, im not, so i have a few things to say. the youtube is 45 minutes compiled from a whole day of shooting — and, of course, obscures a tremendous amount of context, nuance, and chronology — that said, i want to be clear about something: i will never apologize for refusing to normalize misinformation/bigotry. ill have a conversation with almost anybody, but i won’t posture as polite/calm when conversations are this consequential. im not sorry that i care — and that it shows. that said, there are, still, a million things i wish i articulated/did differently — and im still transparently questioning if i made the right choice participating in this at all. i know how enormously privileged i am to live my life/have access to conversations like this — and it’s my hope that i reckoned with that responsibly. there’s definitely a lot about how it’s edited that glosses over conversations about precisely that (and sensationalizes quite a bit) — but i encourage you to watch the whole thing to decide for yourself how you feel bc im tbh still deciding how i feel about all of it myself. all i can say at this point is that as you can tell, this debate definitely riled me up — and i couldn’t have gotten through it without @ellenacuario @yazi_nay @yulingwu @jkabobs, may we continue to find power/community/strength in each other as we work towards better ❤️ #stopasianhate #representationmatters #inshallah #linkinbio

ive been struggling to find the words for 2022 — so i turned to counting. and i momentarily felt proud of myself — that for the first time, i was counting birthday parties attended as comparably important to speeches delivered. that i had lived a year with a little more deviance from the hamster wheel — where in small ways, i did scary things that a past version of me could’ve never imagined. but a friend recently challenged me on my thinking, that i wasn’t really meaningfully escaping my toxic mindsets — but instead perhaps retrofitting my familiarity with professional metrics to my personal life. that i was still counting — rather than living.

and this video, on the other hand, shows me “living” — but does a really shitty job of showcasing what the last year actually looked like. a year of dreams coming true — and dreams phenomenally falling apart. a year where i mostly felt like i was running on empty. a year where i survived by discovering second winds within me, in large parts due to incredible kindness folks in my life continue to show me even when i don’t deserve it. and while yes, im proud of all that, the truth is, i didn’t achieve many of my goals for the year.

i told myself in the beginning of 2022 that i would prioritize maintenance — that i would try to free myself from a mindset where every year has to be better than the last. but here i am, still searching for data points that convince myself that i did “enough.” in my first full calendar year since graduation, i am searching for “grades” where they do not exist.

this video shows flashy highlights — but those moments are not what i am most proud of. i am most proud of when i let myself watch TV when i had more emails to do because i was feeling really anxious/sad. i am most proud of that this might be the first post ive ever posted without running it by people first to seek validation. i am proud of that while this year didn’t at all go according to plan, that i feel like the most honest version of myself that ive ever been.

so, in 2023, idk that i have a “plan” at all. i just pray for a #newyear with more truth, more integrity, more growth, more peace, more living, less counting. #inshallah

turning twenty four today — excruciatingly aware that it almost feels silly to still care this much about birthdays. 

as we get older, each individual year is a smaller percentage of our life lived than the year prior — thus perhaps rendering it less significant, less noteworthy, less deserving of celebration. and sometimes, it also does feel that way. as an adult turning a non-milestone number this year — there’s no new grade im entering, no “right” (legal, cultural, or otherwise) gained access to, nothing really that makes 24 feel any different than 23. 

but yet, here i am in New Zealand with some of my best friends for my 24th — after having already celebrated in Montecito/LA with so many of my faves. and i am also known for my gratuitously long birthday texts (not unlike these captions), so why? 

because, to me, birthdays are our our chance to show up. for each other. for ourselves. im a big believer in not leaving things unsaid — and so birthdays are our chance to communicate exactly how much folks mean to us — our chance to celebrate the living. so today, im celebrating that im living. what a privilege to live, to love, to be loved. and as we keep growing up — i pray we never stop showing up.

this is a post about audacity. 

i feel extraordinary privileged in so many ways — but as i get older, especially in regards to being audacious. 

when i think about where any of my “success” has come from, a lot it has been a result of me *believing* (often rather presumptuously) that i *could* (whether or not there was any evidence to back that) — and so i just *did* (which was also made possible because so many of obstacles that exist for others did not exist for me). 

so, what does this look like? 

i went back to campus this past weekend for the first time in a year. and at a friends birthday party, a student came up to me say that it was an honor to meet me (which, i know, is wild) — but specifically he felt that way because he did one of my speeches in speech/debate (declamation) — and he went pretty far with it. that speech? a random tedx talk i gave when i was eighteen. 

well, how did that tedx talk happen? because i was visiting a new city with friends, so i just looked on the @ted website to see if any events were happening while i was around — and saw that one was happening at some high school. so, i emailed them asking if they wanted me to speak — and they said yes. 

and so, now, here i am what feels like a lifetime later — after a really long week at work — feeling *so* validated/touched because i had the audacity when i was teenager to throw my hat in the ring. and when i look around today, i see friendships that mean the world to me — that i made because i just dm’d an actor after watching a movie with them in it because i liked their vibe/felt like we were meant to know each other. i see so many magical opportunities that happened because i dared to ask, because of my presumptuous audacity that provokes me to shoot my shot even when i have no business being on the field. 

and i know that audacity is born from privilege. cismale privilege. socioeconomic privilege. community around me believing in me privilege. but i wish for a world where every kid has the privilege to be audacious — to be believe they can — to believe they will. and i plan to never stop fighting for that world, inshallah.

representation unquestionably matters, but as i say in the last slide — representation itself is not enough.

i was asked recently in an interview about what this next generation considers to be beautiful — and the only word that came to mind was “truth.” that in a world where it seems that gaslighting, misleading, and posturing have become ostensibly ubiquitous — that honesty is refreshing. moreover, that in a world that often makes it feel like we need to self-edit perpetually in order to feel pretty, that moments that give us permission to feel inherently enough in our skin are everything.

and representation allows more of us to have those moments — to feel seen, to feel heard, to feel inspired. but it’s not itself enough because there is a tremendous danger in a single story becoming the whole story — in misrepresentation. and i grapple with that every day speaking as a genzer, as a muslim, as a south-asian. i ask myself every day: what does responsible representation look like?

and i think of silly ads — but also of fighting to make @muntyyale look like it does today.

i cannot speak on behalf of billions, but i can speak on what i have learned on my journey — and i can hopefully use what ever access i have to the podium to advocate for better. like @auliicravalho did at #thepower premiere to bring light to #nomorestolensisters, like @dylanmulvaney did at #Day365LIVE by so beautifully representing her communities, like the #TennesseeThree are doing right now to protect kids from preventable gun violence, like @travismontaque is doing with @groupblack.co to empower Black communities, like the students i met in Mexico are doing to champion change. and on this page, we say thank you, ily.

im grateful that more panels look like the world that we live in (and thank you @dentsuusa for having me on this amazing one) — but i am also hopeful that *actually* triggers positive change. more of us having microphones doesn’t mean much if we just recycle the same talking points. so i hope to continue to learn from/be inspired by folks who are making audiences uncomfortable with their truth — and i can think of nothing more beautiful than that. #representationmatters

this #earthday, im really excited to announce that im now a brand ambassador for @toms_of_maine, partnering with them in 2023 as a part of their Goodness Circle. i talk a lot about purpose-driven business, and Tom’s of Maine is a brand really walking the walk, taking steps to do real good. they are all about action, so that we can be happy people living on a happy planet. and this #earthmonth, im p grateful for that. certainly lots more to come though — from content to impact. #ad #tomsofmainepartner #goodnesscircle #bcorp #touchgrass #nyc

me in the @guardian 
✍️ by amelia tait 
📸 by @_serenabrown 
🗣️ claim that i can whisper, certainly not by me — but i did say (yell?) some things in this story that you can scroll through here 
#genz #theguardian #marketing #socialimpact #founderstory #photoshoot #grateful #reflection

what a reminder ramadan, eid, and the last few days have been that ultimately even amidst all the fomo this app increasingly inspires — all that really matters is faith, friends, and family. i will not remember the contract that didn’t close or the event i wasn’t invited to, but i will remember slide ten for as long as i live. alhamdullilah for that — for all of it.

i was recently pressed on how gen z employees are “impossible.” and i responded with how i think all gen z is asking for is to live a life worth living. that for too long people were forced into deeply unfair circumstances bc “this is the way it is.” but i think the pandemic demonstrated that a radically different world *is* possible — triggering many of us to ask ourselves if *this* world is working. and i think a lot of us arrived at “no” in that reflection, with young people uniquely at a life stage to channel that “no” into a rejection of norms as is, into a reimagination that serves more of us.

i asserted that a life worth living is perhaps where we can answer “why?” to whatever we are doing, where we actually like our answer. but i think i was wrong. because the most precious moments often have no “why” — like karaoke with my sisters just because (ie. last slide).

moreover, in taking my Nani to the White House, ive reflected on her journey to come to this country — and i realize she likely didn’t always have a good “why?”— but she regrets none of it. she has lived a life of sacrifice, obligation, and faith — and she has done so with grace, love, and conviction. but i imagine many genzers wouldn't want to have led her life, but she would choose it again — and again — and again.

so as i grapple with that tension. and with the tension of being an employer who is also fiercely on the side of employees advocating for better. i pause. i realize that perhaps the very notion that i (or anyone) can decide what constitutes a life worth living is foolish. and so the question isn't what defines a life worth living, the question is am i living a life that works for me? and idk rn. my world is equal parts magic and madness, and some days that feels like where i belong — and some days like i am stranger to my own peace. i romanticize though *breaking free,* living differently — and i am deeply privileged that i could if i chose to.

so to me, the question becomes are we creating a society that empowers people to ask why — to have agency to do something about it. and the ask becomes for anyone with power to be invested in ensuring that tmw is possible, for all of us.

year two being/speaking at @cannes_lions. year one of bringing some of my team/people along with me. reflecting heavy on how i am only in any of these spaces because people have said my name in rooms that i was not in, have held the door open after themselves for me, have allowed me to pull in others behind me. may we at @juvconsulting forever be those people — who continue to jam the door open for more of us — who champion more diverse young voices disrupting these spaces always — with purpose, with play, with power. #canneslions2023 #industrybesties #zcon #her #jackharlow #florenceandthemachine #asaprocky #disclosure #europetravel
it’s nice out! let’s #getintonature - and ensure everyone gets to! link in bio to learn more about @tomsofmaine’s Get Into Nature program! #tomsofmainepartner #ad

if any part of this resonates with you, you’re gonna wanna be at @zcon.xyz, the first major conference with only Gen Z speakers in LA on 8/3/23 — all thanks to our tremendous sponsors like @snapchat @dove @axe @beyondmeat @invisalign @starrylemonlime + more — passing the mic/giving the mainstage to gen z icons like @thechelseamiller @kahlil.greene @zariaparvez @elliezeiler @julesterpak @pinkmantaray @iamavantika @aditimayer @queerbrownvegan @amandadiaz — a moment to live the @juvconsulting values that i spoke about here in remarks to @clintonglobal — a tangible manifestation of the intersectional, intergenerational future we’ve been pushing for. link in bio if you wanna be there/be involved. this is the most exciting thing we’ve ever done, so see y’all soon besties ❤️

@zcon.xyz is exactly one week a way — so in seven days, this truly phenomenal slate of gen zers will take to the stage to center *our* voices instead of watching folks constantly speaking *for* us. a boy is real tired from planning for this event, but knows how endlessly he will be energized from sharing space with these souls. grateful to be in community w every face on here — truly the line-up of my gen z dreams ❤️‍🔥 thanks always to our sponsors for believing in us — and to my @juvconsulting team who makes it all happen 🫶🏽 #zcon #genz #marketing #conference #losangeles

there is a lot that i don’t like about my job, but @zcon.xyz is the crystallization of everything that i do love about it.

i often talk about the glamorization of entrepreneurship, but if there is anything to actually romanticize about this role it is the joy of looking at a blank canvas, visualizing an idea, and then making that vision into reality. there is nothing quite like making your own imagination tangible.

and #zcon has been the vision for a long while. i may not be in school anymore, but zcon feels like the thesis of my last decade. a physical manifestation in our fervent belief in the power of diverse young voices, in the necessity of community-first business, in the possibility of daring to color outside the lines.

and we proved our hypothesis. that when gen z gets to build the table, set the menu, curate the guestlist — it’s magic. and as these pictures show, a week ago in LA, we held the first conference of its kind — the first industry convening w *only* gen z speakers, with executives there to *listen.* there was no playbook for us doing this, no example of a summit with recess, prom, intentional intergenerational confrontations, and action sites throughout the city to live a generation’s values. and certainly no one on our team of scrappy young people had ever done this before.

but we did it. we really did it.

but much like writing a thesis, or being the first to do anything, it has winded us. creating a snapsterpiece on a blank canvas was only made possible by extraordinary contributions from our @juvconsulting team, from our generous sponsors (like @snapchat), from our unrivaled line-up of speakers, from our impactful partners, from 500+ attendees who brought positive energy into the space. there are no words to overstate my gratitude.

in twenty years, i will not remember what deals i did or didn't close. i will not remember the million things that could have gone better in making this event come together. i will not even remember how tired i feel right now. i will remember how my community rallied for me, for us. i will remember what we proved was possible, what it felt like to bask in that possibility with all my besties by my side.

my dear dadu, sakina ahmed, has passed away after a year-long battle with cancer. 

when i think of dadu, i think of a woman who made me endless amounts of shemai because she defined cooking with love, who deserves an oscar for her otherworldly bargaining skills, and who never wore a pair of pants in her life (wore stunning saris even to sleep). 

my dadu was the furthest thing from a trope of a Bangladeshi grandma though. she was 4’10, but she was a giant. she didn’t have more than a middle school education, but she was perhaps the smartest person i have ever known. she self-taught herself english, still using it fluently (and evocatively) until her last breath. 

she was a complicated woman. and i think that stemmed from her being unbelievably fierce. she unapologetically said what everyone else was thinking out loud, stood unbothered even if all scrutinizing eyes were on her, and didn’t let *anyone* get away w foolishness.

i asked her recently if she ever wondered what she would have been in a world that allowed her to be more because i often imagine if she was born today that she would have been a badass CEO or a reality TV star — and her response was simply “chup.” she had no interest in imagining what she *could* have done because she gave her life so that we could instead. 

my dadu was a firecracker — and any amount of *fire* that exists within me/my sisters is largely from her. we didn’t just inherit her spunk though — but id like to think also her candor, her humor, her zeal. she didn’t just march to the beat of her own drum, she strutted to the tune of her own damn marching band. 

whether that was with her brazen jokes, her bold lipsticks, or her exclaiming at the hospital that she was so mad no one ever gave halal chicken nuggets to her before me that day — she was always vocal. but even being absolutely hysterical, she always tried to hide her laugh — her contagious, full-body, radiant laugh. 

but what i will remember is my Dadu being loud, loving, and laughing. and i will thank God every day that i got to laugh with her — that i got to be loudly loved by her. 

‎إِنَّا ِلِلَّٰهِ وَإِنَّا إِلَيْهِ رَاجِعُونَ

We hear too often about the power of young people, but rarely see enough empowering of young people — and even more rarely see that empowering of young people look like the funding, amplifying, and platforming that diverse Gen Zers deserve. That’s why I’m so proud to continue to be partnering with @toms_of_maine as they bring their Incubator back for a second year, an initiative to resource the next generation of climate leaders from marginalized communities. If you are an underrepresented voice doing work to save our planet, please apply as applications are open now until October 15th. #TomsOfMainePartner

It was an honor to be on this Tom’s of Maine panel at @thenestclimatecampus alongside @arsemathomas, @alexia.leclercq, @queerbrownvegan, and Michelle during #climateweek to really center this work/conversation — and to announce the second year of their Incubator.

The Incubator offers real funding, mentorship, in-person convenings, and broad amplification. @toms_of_maine also had superstars like @wawa_gatheru, who spoke at ZCON, as a part of the program last year — so you’ll certainly be in good company. Tom’s of Maine is empowering our generation to do good, for real. And in a sea of brands just talking the walk, it means a lot to see Tom’s of Maine continuing to walk the walk. And that gives me hope, genuinely (as discussed in the clip above). More information is in my link in bio! Apply now! #TomsOfMaineIncubator #TomsOfMaine #contest

No purchase necessary. Open to legal residents of the 50 U.S. and D.C. (including DACA recipients), 18-30 at time of entry whose personal background or characteristics have impeded their access or exposure to fields of climate, environmental science, and/or sustainability. Begins 10:00 am ET on 9/19/23; ends 11:59 pm ET on 10/15/23. For Official Rules, www.tomsofmaineincubator.com.
Yale ‘21 | NYC | CEO of @juvconsulting | @forbes #30Under30 | american-muslim speaker
